{"step_by_step_thinking": "The question is asking for the probability that a subject will have a hemoglobin concentration greater than 18 g/dL. Given that the data is normally distributed, we can use the properties of a normal distribution to answer this question. In a normal distribution, approximately 68% of values fall within one standard deviation of the mean, 95% fall within two standard deviations, and 99.7% fall within three standard deviations. In this case, the mean is 17 g/dL and the standard error is 0.1 g/dL. Therefore, a hemoglobin concentration of 18 g/dL is 10 standard deviations away from the mean (18 - 17 = 1, 1 / 0.1 = 10). Given that 99.7% of values fall within three standard deviations of the mean, it is extremely unlikely that a subject will have a hemoglobin concentration greater than 18 g/dL.", "answer_choice": "D"}
